Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Analysis of signaling partners of RPK1 and TOAD2 in radial patterning

ProgramReference.Text: US CHINA COOP IN BASIC SCIENCE

POR.DRECONTENT:
Funding from NSF provided travel and training at a Chinese University to gain research experience, learn about research policies, and the language and culture of this foreign country.  The present research proposal focuses on molecular aspects of plant development that has the potential to establish mechanisms for improving development, fitness and biomass production.

            Early embryonic development in Arabidopsis plants involves the establishment of a radial patterning axis, superimposed on an apical-basal axis serving as a framework for further pattern elaboration. For example, to reach the first stage of differentiated embryo development the cells initially forming a globular mass have to divide such that inner, middle and outer layers of specialized tissue arise. To date, the mechanisms by which radial patterning occurs in differentiating cells of the embryo or mature organs are not well understood, but the available experimental data suggests cell-cell signaling is required for proper patterning. Similar to other species, Arabidopsis plants contain a huge number of receptor like kinases (RLKs), special proteins embedded in the plasma membrane. Owing to their structure, spanning the membrane and exposing functional domains on the outside, as well as inside the cell they are likely to function in signal relays.  Their representation in the plant genome at more than 2.5% of total protein encoding genes suggests that RLKs signaling is important in all aspects of development, including radial patterning.

            Recent research performed in our laboratory using reverse genetics in Arabidopsis showed that two closely related RLKs named RPK1 (RECEPTOR PROTEIN KINASE1). and TOAD2 (TOADSTOOL2) are redundantly required for embryonic pattern formation. My hypothesis is that cell-cell communication, mediated through RLKs, takes place between radial layers at specific times of development One of the major goals of my research is to characterize components of the signaling pathway involving RPK1 and TOAD2. Identifying complex protein interactions in the context of RPK1/TOAD2 signaling will address a critical question in plant developmental biology that has deep implications in our understanding of radial pattern formation. This information could be potentially used to infer new methods to improve root and stem architecture in crop plants, in a similar way it was recently proposed for leaf morphology in rice using findings in Arabidopsis.

            During this funding period I worked with the collaborating Chinese scientists on this project, exploring unique and complimentary biochemical approaches. Sharing methodology and expertise between our laboratories provided for a broader learning experience in a collaborative international setting. Beyond the laboratory work, I was fortunate to learn about the agricultural research at the Lanzhou University, China and the more general arid climate challenges in agriculture.  Establishing collaborations and meeting other researchers in the field of rice and barley research established transnational ties that will be essential to establish work connections, after my graduation, when I plan to pursue projects involving research in major crops.
